chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with suspected or confirmed gonorrhoea infection.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

Signs and symptoms in a woman

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with suspected gonorrhoea in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Assess all people suspected of having gonorrhoea infection.
  • Ideally, refer all people with confirmed or suspected gonorrhoea to a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic or other local specialist sexual health service.
  • If these services cannot be accessed within a reasonable time, or if the person is unwilling to attend, the person can be managed in primary care if the appropriate expertise is available. 
    • Confirm the diagnosis, preferably using nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT), according to local protocols and procedures.
    • If NAAT positive for gonorrhoea, take swabs for culture before prescribing antibiotics to enable sensitivity testing and identification of resistant strains.
    • Treat for gonorrhoea.
    • Offer screening for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and for HIV.
    • Encourage patient-led partner notification.
      • Partners should be screened for STIs and treated empirically for gonorrhoea whilst awaiting results.
    • Advise the person to abstain from sex until they, and any partners, have completed treatment. 
      • If azithromycin is used, this will be 7 days after treatment is given.
    • Follow-up after 1 week to verify the success of treatment.
      • Test of cure is recommended for all people who have been treated for gonorrhoea.
    • Provide appropriate information and advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2011], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the World Health Organization (WHO) Treatment of Neisseria gonorrhoeae [WHO, 2016], and the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Gonorrhoea infection [BMJ, 2016].

  • The complexities of gonorrhoea management, especially contact tracing, can be challenging. As a result people should be referred promptly to specialists in genito-urinary medicine (GUM) for management [RCGP, 2013].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I treat a person with gonorrhoea in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Treat gonorrhoea in primary care only if specialist services cannot be accessed within a reasonable time, or if the person is unwilling to attend despite receiving appropriate information and advice.
  • Treatment is indicated following a positive identification of Neisseria gonorrhoeae. For more information see the section on Diagnosis.
    • Before prescribing antibiotics a culture should be taken to test for susceptibility and identify resistant strains.
  • Empirical treatment is indicated for:
    • Recent sexual partners of people with confirmed gonococcal infection. 
  • In the unusual event that confirmed or suspected uncomplicated anogenital gonorrhoea needs to be treated in primary care, prescribe:
    • Ceftriaxone 1 g intramuscular (IM) injection as a single dose.
      • If this regimen is unsuitable or unavailable, contact the local microbiology or genito-urinary medicine clinic for advice.
  • In the unusual event that confirmed uncomplicated anogenital or pharyngeal gonorrhoea needs to be treated in primary care, and the antimicrobial susceptibility is known prior to treatment prescribe:
    • Ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally as a single dose.
      • If this regimen is unsuitable or unavailable, contact the local microbiology or genito-urinary medicine clinic for advice.

Alternative regimens

  • These alternative regimens may be given because of allergy, needle phobia or other absolute or relative contraindications.
    • Cefixime 400 mg orally as a single dose plus azithromycin 2 g orally.
      • Only advisable if an intramuscular injection is contraindicated or refused by the patient.
    • Gentamicin 240 mg intramuscularly as a single dose plus azithromycin 2 g orally.
    • Spectinomycin 2 g intramuscularly as a single dose plus azithromycin 2 g orally.
      • Spectinomycin is not recommended for pharyngeal infection because of poor efficacy.
    • Azithromycin 2 g as a single oral dose.
      • The clinical efficacy of azithromycin does not always correlate with in vitro susceptibility testing and azithromycin resistance is high.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2019] a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the World Health Organization (WHO) Treatment of Neisseria gonorrhoeae [WHO, 2016], and the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Gonorrhoea infection [BMJ, 2016].

Ceftriaxone dose
  • BASSH guideline recommend ceftriaxone 1 g intramuscular (IM) injection as a single dose [BASHH, 2019].
Use of quinolone antibiotics
  • Treatment with ciprofloxacin is only recommended if N. gonorrhoeae is known to be quinolone sensitive, as there is a high prevalence of quinolone resistance worldwide [BASHH, 2019].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What treatment should I prescribe for a woman who is pregnant, or breastfeeding?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• In the unusual event that confirmed or suspected uncomplicated anogenital gonorrhoea needs to be treated in primary care, prescribe: 
    • Ceftriaxone 1 g intramuscular (IM) injection as a single dose.
    • Do not prescribe a fluoroquinolone for a woman who is pregnant or breastfeeding. Seek specialist advice if a cephalosporin is contraindicated, for example if the woman has a true allergy to penicillin.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2019], the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2011], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the World Health Organization (WHO) Treatment of Neisseria gonorrhoeae [WHO, 2016], the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Gonorrhoea infection [BMJ, 2016], expert opinion in a medical textbook Mandell, Douglas, and Bennett's principles and practice of infectious diseases [Marrazzo et al, 2010], the British National Formulary [BNF 73, 2017] and the manufacturers' Summary of Product Characteristics for Ceftriaxone [ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2017], Cefixime [ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015], Azithromycin [ABPI, 2016a] and Ciprofloxacin [ABPI, 2016b]. 

  • Ceftriaxone should only be used in pregnancy if the benefits outweigh the risks [BNF 73, 2017]. 
    • Left untreated, gonorrhoea in pregnancy is associated with spontaneous abortion, premature labour, early rupture of fetal membranes, perinatal mortality, and gonococcal conjunctivitis in the newborn [Marrazzo et al, 2010].
  • Cefixime is not known to be harmful in pregnancy [BNF 73, 2017].
    • The recommendation that cefixime can be used as an alternative to ceftriaxone in pregnancy is based on the BASHH and the WHO guidelines [BASHH, 2011; WHO, 2016].
  • Azithromycin should only be used in pregnancy or for breastfeeding women if adequate alternatives are not available [BNF 73, 2017]. 
  • Fluoroquinolones are not recommended in pregnancy or breastfeeding [ABPI, 2016b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give a person with gonorrhoea?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person to attend a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic or other local specialist sexual health service if possible.
  • Discuss the long-term implications if gonorrhoea is left untreated for the health of the person and their partners. For more information, see the section on complications.
    • Reinforce this information with clear and accurate written material where available, for example, the Family Planning Association (FPA) patient information leaflet Gonorrhoea. 
  • Provide information about the:
    • Treatment of gonorrhoea and possible adverse effects.
    • Need for partner notification.
    • Follow up required.
  • Advise the person to abstain from sex until they and any partners have completed treatment. 
    • If azithromycin is used, this will be 7 days after treatment is given.
  • Advise the person about using safer sexual practice in the future.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2011], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], and the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Gonorrhoea infection [BMJ, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What follow up is required for a person with gonorrhoea?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Follow up all people with gonorrhoea about 1 week after treatment to:
    • Confirm that the person has adhered to treatment and symptoms have resolved.
    • Ask about adverse reactions.
    • Confirm that partner notification has been carried out.
    • Ask about recent sexual history (and the possibility of re-infection), and reinforce advice about safe sexual practice.
  • A test of cure (TOC) is recommended for all people who have been treated for gonorrhoea.
    • If the person is asymptomatic, test with nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) where available (followed by culture if positive), at least 2 weeks after completion of treatment.
    • If signs or symptoms persist, test with culture, performed at least 3 days after completion of treatment.
      • Consider additional testing with NAAT (for increased sensitivity) after one week if culture is negative.
    • If it is not possible or practical to perform a test of cure in all people treated for gonorrhoea, prioritize the following groups:
      • People with persistent signs or symptoms.
      • People with pharyngeal infection.
      • People who have been treated with anything other than the first-line recommendation.
  • All failures of antibiotics must be reported to Public Health England.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2011], and the Health Protection Surveillance Centre (HPSC) National guidelines for prevention and control of gonorrhoea and for minimising the impact of antimicrobial resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoea [HPSC, 2016].

Test of cure
  • Both BASHH and HPSC recommend a test of cure (TOC) for all cases of gonorrhoea [BASHH, 2011; HPSC, 2016].
    • Additional testing with NAAT for increased sensitivity can be considered one week after culture, if it is negative [HPSC, 2016].
  • However, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that TOC is not needed for uncomplicated urogenital or rectal gonorrhoea treated with the recommended regimens [CDC, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer, or admit a person with gonorrhoea?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ideally, refer all people with suspected or confirmed gonorrhoea to a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic or other local specialist sexual health service.
  • Refer the following people to the appropriate speciality: 
    • Women who are pregnant.  
    • Women with suspected ascending infection. For more information, see the CKS topics on Pelvic inflammatory disease.
    • People with complications. For example epididymitis or prostatitis in men. For more information, see the CKS topic on Prostatitis - acute.
    • People with conjunctival gonorrhoea.
    • People who have not responded to treatment.
    • People allergic to cephalosporins.
  • Admit under the following circumstances:
    • People with suspected disseminated gonorrhoea (systemic symptoms may be present, such as fever, malaise, joint pain and swelling, and rash).
    • Women with pelvic inflammatory disease if it is severe or there are complications. For more information, see the CKS topics on Pelvic inflammatory disease.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2011], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Gonorrhoea infection [BMJ, 2016], the International Union against Sexually Transmitted Infections (IUSTI) 2012 European guideline on the diagnosis and treatment of gonorrhoea in adults [Bignell, 2012], the Medical Foundation for HIV & Sexual Health (MEDFASH) Standards for the management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) [MEDFASH, 2014], and what CKS considers good clinical practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When and how should partners be notified?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Partner notification is essential for all people with newly diagnosed gonorrhoea. Ideally this should be done by a trained health adviser in genito-urinary medicine (GUM). If this is not possible, it may be done by a primary healthcare professional who has undergone appropriate training and has support from healthcare advisers in GUM.
    • For men with symptomatic anogenital gonorrhoea, all sexual partners within the preceding 2 weeks should be notified, or their most recent partner, if this was longer than 2 weeks ago.
    • For all other people (women, men with asymptomatic gonorrhoea or gonorrhoea at other sites) all partners within the preceding 3 months should be notified.
  • Notified partners should be offered testing and be treated empirically whilst waiting for results.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2011], and a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013]
